classTitle: Emissions, global warming potentials and the global carbon cycle

body:
Welcome to the Software for Climate course!
 
This is a cohort-based course. It runs for eight weeks, with two classes per week. Each class involves three learning components:
  1. Async reading materials, presented in slides like this one
  2. Live sessions involving lecutures, audience participation, group discussions, and Q&A
  3. Homework assignments
Additionally, we have a cohort slack channel for ad hoc communication with the instructors and your fellows in the cohort
 
You will get the most out of this course if you:
  1. Complete the reading assignments ahead of the live sessions
  2. Attend the live sessions in person
  3. Actively participate to build a community with your fellows in the cohort via the slack and during group discussions in the live sessions
These async slides will present the learning objectives for the class and link out to external reading materials.

For the course overall:
  1. Big picture view of the software x climate landscape
  2. Dive deeps into four topics that are particularly relevant to climate tech, with hands-on learning
    1. Public data sources
    2. Geospatial + AI
    3. Energy Modeling
    4. Software/hardware interfaces
  3. Final portfolio project
  4. Build a community with like-minded individuals. Who knows, maybe you'll find a cofounder and start a company together with one of your fellows! Or get a warm intro to the hiring manager at your dream job.
For class 1.1:
  1. Course overview & housekeeping
  2. Start building community
  3. Intro to class tools

body:
This course does not require professional software engineering experience, but assumes a basic level of familiarity with code. 
 
In the class, you’ll be reading, modifying, and extending existing Python code written in Hex interactive notebooks
 
Depending on your familiarity with code in general and Python specifically, we recommend you review one of these resources:
  • If you already write python, close your laptop and grab a beer, you’re all set!
  • If you already write code but not python, spend up to 1 hour reviewing this:
    • Python cheat sheet & quick reference
  • If you rarely write code, spend up to 2 hours reviewing one of these:
    • Python tutorial (free) - chapters 3 & 4 are the most relevant for this course
    • Python tutorial (paid) - an interactive tutorial by Codecademy (7-day free trial period)
 
We'll introduce Hex notebooks as we get to them, but if you're chomping at the bit to learn more now, get started with this:
  • A beginner’s guide to Python notebooks
See you in the first live session!
We will be moving into the next section now, on the global carbon cycle. Feel free to pause, get some water, walk around, take a few deep breaths, relax, or take a nap! And return later if you need.
We're going to shift into a little workshop now on stocks, flows and concentrations of carbon. If you need a break, this is a good point to pause!
